prompt: Facts: The respondents, Deokaran Nenshi and Ramnibas Nessaria, were owners of the Pakuria Stone Quarry in the Sub-Division of Jamtara.; On December 25, 1960, Shri L. Paswan, Inspector of Mines, inspected the quarry.; During the inspection, it was found that the respondents had failed to furnish the half-yearly returns for the periods ending June 30, 1960, and December 31, 1960.; This non-submission was alleged to be a contravention of Regulation 19(1)(b) of the Indian Metalliferous Mines Regulations, 1926 (read with the Mines Act, 1952).; Regulation 19(1)(b) required owners, agents, or managers of mines to submit half-yearly returns in the prescribed Form II-A on or before the 21st day of July and the 21st day of January each year.; A complaint was filed by the State of Bihar against the respondents on April 12, 1961, before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Jamtara.; The complaint alleged contravention of Regulation 19(1)(b) punishable under Section 66 of the Mines Act, 1952.; The respondents were summoned to face trial.; The Trial Magistrate acquitted the respondents, holding that the prosecution was barred by limitation under Section 79 of the Mines Act, 1952.; The State of Bihar appealed to the High Court, which upheld the acquittal.; The State of Bihar then appealed to the Supreme Court of India.; The key legal issue was whether the failure to furnish returns by the specified dates constituted a 'continuing offence', thereby saving the prosecution from the limitation period prescribed in Section 79 of the Mines Act. | IPC: No IPC sections were directly charged or formed the basis of the prosecution in this case. The charges were under the Mines Act, 1952 and the Indian Metalliferous Mines Regulations, 1926.
